column1: #Text=A Very Dull Affair X. Strange but True XI .
#Text=“ There ’s ingratitude for you ! ” Miss Dolly Foster exclaimed suddenly .
#Text=“ Where ! ” I asked , rousing myself from meditation .
#Text=She pointed to a young man who had just passed where we sat .
#Text=He was dressed very smartly , and was walking with a lady attired in the height of the fashion .
#Text=“ I made that man , ” said Dolly , “ and now he cuts me dead before the whole of the Row !
#Text=Why , but for me , do you suppose he ’d be at this moment engaged to three thousand a year and -- and the plainest girl in London ? ”
#Text=“ Not that , ” I pleaded ; “ think of -- ”
#Text=I was quite ready to bow to him .
#Text=“ Oh , well , you did n’t then .
#Text=“ I met him , ” said Miss Dolly , “ three years ago .
#Text=He was everything he should n’t be .
#Text=He was a teetotaler , you know , and he did n’t smoke , and he was always going to concerts .
#Text=Oh , and he wore his hair long , and his trousers short , and his hat on the back of his head .
#Text=Carried it unrolled , you know , and generally a paper parcel in the other hand ; and he had spectacles too . ”
#Text=“ He has certainly changed , outwardly at least .
#Text=“ Yes , I know ; well , I did that .
#Text=I took him in hand , and I just taught him , and now -- ! ”
#Text=Give him Saturday evening lectures , or what ? ”
#Text=“ Oh , every-evening lectures , and most-morning walks .
#Text=And I taught him to dance , and broke his wretched fiddle with my own hands ! ”
#Text=“ What very arbitrary distinctions you draw ! ”
#Text=“ I do n’t know that you mean .
#Text=I do like a man to be smart , anyhow .
#Text=You ’re not so smart as you might be .
#Text=Now , shall I take you in hand ? ”
#Text=I just slipped in a remark here and there , whenever he talked nonsense .
#Text=I used to speak just at the right time , you know . ”
#Text=“ But how had your words such influence , Miss Foster ? ”
#Text=“ Oh , well , you know , Mr. Carter , I made it a condition that he should do just what I wanted in little things like that .
#Text=Did he think I was going to walk about with a man carrying a brown paper parcel -- as if we had been to the shop for a pound of tea ? ”
#Text=“ Still , I do n’t see why he should alter all his -- ”
#Text=Of course , he liked me , you know . ”
#Text=“ You seem to think that very funny . ”
#Text=“ Not that he did -- but that , apparently , he does n’t . ”
#Text=“ Well you got out of that rather neatly -- for you .
#Text=He thought -- well , I do believe he thought I cared for him , you know .
#Text=“ Just as a friend -- and a pupil , you know .
#Text=And when he ’d had his hair cut and bought a frock coat ( fancy he ’d never had one ! ) , he looked quite nice .
#Text=There is an understanding that I am very unhappy since Miss Foster ’s engagement to the Earl of Mickleham was announced .
#Text=“ What was I saying before -- before you -- you know --
#Text=I did like him very much , you know , or I should n’t have taken all that trouble .
#Text=“ I have no more to say , ” said I.
#Text=“ But she wrote me a horrid letter afterward . ”
#Text=“ You leave so much out , I mean .
#Text=“ Why , after I sent him away .
#Text=Oh , we had the most awful scene .
#Text=He called me the most horrid names , and -- ”
#Text=“ It was n’t long enough to get hold of , ” she tittered .

#Text=And then , next day , when I thought it was comfortably over , you know , he came back , and -- and apologized , and called himself the most awful names , and -- well , that was really worse . ”
#Text=“ What did the fellow complain of ? ” I asked in wondering tones .
#Text=“ Oh , he said I ’d destroyed his faith in women , you know , and that I ’d led him on , and that I was --
#Text=And he went on writing me letters like that for a whole year ?
#Text=“ But he did n’t go back to short trousers and a fiddle , did he ? ” I asked anxiously .
